Across Content Areas

Types of Activities that Provide Valuable Information on Whether Students Are Learning

 How and Why to Conduct these Activities

Discussion among students

Provide students with opportunities to discuss topics and explain their reasoning and understanding to one another in pairs, small groups, large groups.

Presentations

Provide opportunities for students to present on a topic, concept, or problem.  For example, they could conduct a survey, collect and process data, come to conclusions and present them to their classmates.

One-on-one interviews

Interview students, asking them questions that will solicit whether they are making connections; can they see that a problem solving approach can be used in other settings than those you used in class? Also ask questions so you can determine areas they feel confident and those they still feel unsure.
Journaling

Ask students to write out explanations of how they approach problems and descriptions of their experiences doing the work. What was challenging, what was easy, why?  What do feel confident about, what questions do they still have?
Self-Assessment

Students can use rubrics to evaluate their work or grade their own work.Students should have input in developing rubrics.
Peer Assessments

Students should be encouraged to provide feedback on the work of their peers (using rubrics, assessing presentations, providing feedback in discussions, etc.)
Continue the Discussion Outside Classroom

Encourage students to continue their inquiry and dialogue outside of the classroom setting: Assign group projects.

  • Assign work that requires students to consult with one another.
  • Assign work that requires students to interact with people outside of class.
